front.title: SMTP IPv6 to IPv4 Fallback: An Applicability Statement

abstract.t: This Applicability Statement describes how Mail Transfer Agents (MTAs) can be encouraged to fall back to IPv4 when a message is refused over IPv6.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The process of target host selection appears in . SMTP clients in well known Mail Transfer Agent (MTA) software will retry a message using a different Mail Exchanger (MX) or network address if the message is temporarily rejected. This document describes under which circumstances these MTAs can be made to retry over IPv4 when an initial connection to IPv6 results in a temporary rejection. This behavior could be useful in, for instance, enforcing higher requirements for Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) sessions over IPv6 than what exists on IPv4 without simply rejecting the message outright.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Moving from IP Reputation to Domain Based Reputation
section.t: IPv6 brings more IP addresses, which means building an IP-based reputation system using IPv6 addresses will be difficult to achieve. Moving from an IP based reputation system to a domain based reputation system is expected to be easier. However, it requires that all SMTP servers participate.

As IPv6 is still relatively nascent, there is a chance to mandate use of the Sender Policy Framework (SPF, ) or DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM, ) for messages sent over IPv6 and, if these fail, to do retries over IPv4.

section.title: Common Open Source MTA Design
section.t: This secton discusses current implementations in common open source MTAs.

Some observations:
When presented with a permanent failure code (5yz) during connection establishment, some MTA clients will declare the message non deliverable instead of retrying it on a different MX. When an SMTP server rejects during the connection phase using the code 451 and disconnects, the SMTP client will typically retry the message immediately on a different MX. When an SMTP server rejects after the DATA phase using a 421 SMTP reply code followed by a disconnect, the code 421 and disconnect, the SMTP client will retry the message immediately on a different MX.

section.title: Rejecting Messages for Immediate Retry on IPv4
section.t: SMTP clients only interpret SMTP status codes, but the use of SMTP enhanced status codes can be used to better monitor and act on the reason of the temporary failure.

For instance, at the end of DATA, if the message was sent over IPv6, the SMTP server can evalute whether the message passes SPF or DKIM and reject the message using 421 if neither pass. If one passes, then an authenticated domain name is available and domain reputation rules can be applie. The IPv6 address of the SMTP client can be noted, and futher connections over IPv6 can be temporarily failed using the 451 status code for some period of time period so as to minimize resources to evaluate each message after the end of DATA. On the other hand, if a message coming from an IPv6 address does not pass SPF or DKIM, it is unlikely that this state would quickly change for the next message coming from the same network address.

For proprietary mail systems or large mailbox providers, they all do a form of domain authentication, either SPF or DKIM, so the above may not apply to them. Not all are yet enabled to send email over IPv6.

section.title: MX RR configuration
section.t: When a message is temporarily refused, using a 400-series SMTP error code, the strategy for the SMTP client is sometimes to retry immediately to a different MTA, as defined by the target selection process defined in .

When the new MX refers to a dual-stacked machine (see ), some MTA software will not pick up all of the A or AAAA RRs (Resource Records), but will instead select only the RRs matching the address family preferred by the local TCP/IP implementation. Thus, MX RRs SHOULD NOT refer to dual-stacked machines.

figure.preamble: For instance, the following configuration is desired:
figure.artwork: example.org. IN MX 10 mx1.example.org. IN MX 10 mx1-6.example.org. mx1.example.org. IN A 192.0.2.1 mx1-6.example.org. IN AAAA 2001:db8:ffff::1

section.t: In this configuration, the SMTP clients see two MXes at the same precedence, and will automatically pick one and try the other one if the message is properly temp-failed. [MSK: But isn't that what you want to happen?]

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: SMTP clients might not not fall back to IPv4 when requested (by not implementing this proposal) and keep retrying on IPv6. MTA administrators ought to monitor for such servers, and could whitelist them to accept messages over IPv6 or take other action as appropriate.
